section.title: Installation Assumptions
section.para: The installation method described in this guide is for JBoss Developer Studio, built around Eclipse and packaged with all of the necessary dependencies and third party plug-ins. To ensure successful installation, a number of assumptions are made about your system:

listitem.para: Your system meets the system requirements for installing JBoss Developer Studio 7, as set out in JBoss Developer Studio 7 Installation Guide. The system requirements concern having a compatible operating system, sufficient computer memory and a compatible Java developer kit.
You are aware of the Visual Page Editor tool limitations on 64-bit OS X and Microsoft Windows operating systems and will use the workaround detailed in JBoss Developer Studio 7 Installation Guide.
You are aware of the BrowserSim tool limitations on Microsoft Windows operating systems and will use the workaround detailed in JBoss Developer Studio 7 Installation Guide.

note.para: If you wish to install JBoss Developer Studio BYOE, you may following the instructions in JBoss Developer Studio 7 Installation Guide and then continue to work through the TicketMonster tutorial in this guide.

para.remark: [QE]A universal installer .jar file is provided for installing JBoss Developer Studio and it is available from the Customer Service Portal. The procedure below guides you though obtaining the universal installer and the installion process.

step.para: Log in to the Customer Service Portal at https://access.redhat.com.
From the menu bar click Downloads then, under JBOSS ENTERPRISE MIDDLEWARE, click Downloads.
From the Product list, select JBoss Developer Studio.
From the JBoss Developer Studio 7 table, click Download for the JBoss Developer Studio 7.0.0 Stand Alone Universal Binary download file.

On the command line, navigate to the location of the universal installer .jar file and enter java -jar jbdevstudio-product_universal-7.0.0.build_version.jar where build_version is substituted to match the name of the .jar file.
To start the installer, you may be able to double-click the .jar file.
To force a 32-bit or 64-bit installation of JBoss Developer Studio, append -d32 or -d64 to the java command, respectively. For example, java -jar -d32 jbdevstudio-product_universal-7.0.0.build_version.jar
When the Installer window opens, click Next.
After reading and agreeing to the terms of the End User License Agreement, click I accept the terms of this license agreement and click Next.

In the Select the installation path field, type the location where you want JBoss Developer Studio to be installed or click Browse to navigate to the desired location. When the Select the installation path field shows the correct location, click Next. When you are prompted about the selected location being created or overwritten, check the message and, if satisfied, click OK.

Default Java VM is automatically selected. Check that the disabled text field contains the path of the JRE in the Java developer kit you want to use. If it does not, click Specific Java JVM and type the path of the JRE in the text field or use the Browse button to select the correct JRE. When the text field shows the correct JRE path, click Next.

To make use of automatic runtime detection for finding runtime servers, click Add and type the path of a runtime server in the Location field or click Browse to navigate to the runtime server location. If you want this path to be scanned for new runtime servers each time JBoss Developer Studio starts, select the Scan every start check box. Click OK to close the Add Location window and click Next.
Check the details in the Summary Information window and, if they are correct, click Next.
Installation commences. When the Pack installation progress bar shows Finished, click Next.
If you want shortcuts to be created for starting JBoss Developer Studio, select the Create shortcuts in the Start-Menu and Create additional shortcut on the desktop check boxes and click Next.

The installation process is now complete. If you want JBoss Developer Studio to automatically start when the Installer window closes, select the Run JBoss Developer Studio after installation check box. Click Done to close the Installer window.

important.para: Linux distributions have a maximum number of files that a process may have open at one time. If this maximum number of files is set too low, JBoss Developer Studio will not start. You must open the /etc/security/limits.conf file and check that the soft nofile and hard nofile variables have values of 9216 at a minimum. If the variables have smaller values, the values must be increased to 9216. If the variables are not specified, the following lines must be added to the file: * soft nofile 9216 * hard nofile 9216

section.title: Select a Workspace Location
section.para: When the IDE starts, you are asked to choose the workspace folder for the session. The workspace is where your projects are stored.

To set the workspace location, follow these steps:
In the Workspace field type the full path of the desired location or use Browse to navigate to the desired location.
If you do not want to be asked to choose a workspace folder each time the development environment starts, select the Use this as the default and do not ask again check box.
Click OK.

The workspace location prompting behavior can be altered at any time by clicking Window→Preferences. Expand General→Startup and Shutdown and select Workspaces. Select or clear the Prompt for workspace on startup check box to alter the behavior as appropriate.

section.title: Set Usage Reporting
section.para: JBoss Developer Studio has usage reporting. At the first start of the development environment after installing, you are asked if you allow the collection of anonymous usage statistics by JBoss Developer Studio. The information collected enables Red Hat to understand how and where JBoss Developer Studio is being used. Specifically, information about operating systems and displays assists to continually improve JBoss Developer Studio.

The following information is collected:
Version of JBoss Developer Studio
Installed components of JBoss Developer Studio
JBoss Central enabled
Origin of Eclipse product
Version of Eclipse
Operating system
Operating system version
Linux distribution and version, if appropriate
Screen colors
Screen resolution
Version of Java
Internet connection type
Location (continent, country, city) and language
User type (new or returning)
Number of times JBoss Developer Studio has been started
Date of first usage reported
Date of last usage reported
Date of current usage reported
If enabled, the usage reporting plug-in uses Google Analytics to track data as though you visited a page under .
To agree to this anonymous information being collected, click Yes when prompted.

The usage reporting behavior can be changed at any time by clicking Window→Preferences. Expand JBoss Tools and select Usage Reporting. Select or clear the Please allow Red Hat Inc. to receive anonymous usage statistics for this JBoss Developer Studio installation check box to alter the behavior as appropriate.
